dialog: Hi Medi, what is pneumonia and how is it caused?

Pneumonia is an infection in the lungs that can be caused by either a virus or bacteria. Primary pneumonia is caused by the initial viral infection, while secondary pneumonia is caused by a secondary bacterial infection.
What are the symptoms?

Symptoms of primary pneumonia include rapid progression of fever, cough, labored breathing, and low oxygen levels that cause bluish skin. Secondary pneumonia typically has a period of improvement in symptoms for 1-3 weeks followed by recurrent fever, sputum production, and fluid buildup in the lungs, but can also occur just a few days after influenza symptoms appear.
What are the most common bacteria that cause pneumonia?
The most frequent bacteria that cause secondary pneumonia are Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus.
Is there a way to prevent pneumonia?

The best way to prevent pneumonia is to maintain good hygiene practices, get vaccinated against viruses that can cause pneumonia, and seek medical attention if you have symptoms of respiratory infection.

Gastrointestinal symptoms may also occur, including nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and gastroenteritis, especially in children.  The standard influenza symptoms typically last for 2 - 8 days.   A 2021 study suggests influenza can cause long lasting symptoms in a similar way to long COVID. Symptomatic infections are usually mild and limited to the upper respiratory tract, but progression to pneumonia is relatively common Influenza Influenza

knowledge: Influenza Influenza  Pneumonia may be caused by the primary viral infection or by a secondary bacterial infection.  Primary pneumonia is characterized by rapid progression of fever, cough, labored breathing, and low oxygen levels that cause bluish skin.  It is especially common among those who have an underlying cardiovascular disease such as rheumatic heart disease.  Secondary pneumonia typically has a period of improvement in symptoms for 1–3 weeks followed by recurrent fever, sputum production, and fluid buildup in the lungs, but can also occur just a few days after influenza symptoms appear.  About a third of primary pneumonia cases are followed by secondary pneumonia, which is most frequently caused by the bacteria Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus. Influenza viruses comprise four species.  Each of the four species is the sole member of its own genus, and the four influenza genera comprise four of the seven genera in the family Orthomyxoviridae Influenza Influenza
